Ca-binding proteins such as calmodulin play a pivotal role in Ca signal transmission and amplification.
Increases in the concentration of intracellular Ca activate specific protein targets, among which Ca/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII) is a critical signal mediator.
In response to an increase in intracellular Ca, Thr-286 of CaMKII is phosphorylated by Ca-calmodulin.

Health is not only related to the absence of the disease.
We need to conceptualize and operationalize what health is.
Increasingly, information about functional status is needed to appreciate the full picture regarding the health of an individual or a population.
An individual's health fundamentally includes their capacity to carry out the full range of actions, activities, and tasks required to fully engage in all areas of human life.
The health state of a person can be described in terms of capacity to carry out a set of tasks or actions.

Tubulointerstitial nephritis (TIN) with infiltration of numerous IgG4-positive plasma cells is the predominant type of kidney lesion.

Fatty acids (fas) are the components of phospholipids in organelle and cellular membranes.
Fatty acids (fas) play important biological roles by maintaining or processing membrane protein function or fluidity.

Among fatty acids (fas), 3-polyunsaturated fatty acids (3-pUFAs) such as eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) are potent anti-inflammatory molecules.

The in vitro ageing of human diploid fibroblasts (hDFs) has been first described by Hayflick and Moorhead.
HDFs have a limited ability to divide when cultured in vitro.
After approximately 50 cell divisions, HDFs enter a state of irreversible proliferative arrest, termed replicative senescence or cellular senescence.

Nanopores are powerful research tools to investigate the structural and dynamic properties of single biomolecules.
Inner diameters of nanopores are a few nanometers.
Molecules follow the size-exclusion principle when passing through nanopores.
Only individual DNA or protein molecules can fit into or pass through a nanopore.
Passing a molecule blocks a nanopore, leading to a transient change in current.
Parameters of the current blockade, such as duration and amplitude, can provide information about the length and size of the molecule.
One of the most widely published and scientifically attractive subjects is the sensing of DNA with nanopores.
An ultimate goal of nanopore studies is to develop an inexpensive method to sequence DNA.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a progressive, autosomal dominantly inherited neurodegenerative disorder.
HD results from the expansion of a CAG repeat in exon 1 of the huntingtin (HTT) gene.
This polyQ-expanded huntingtin protein has a propensity to misfold, making it resistant to proteasomal and autophagy-mediated degradation.
Earlier age of disease onset and more rapid disease progression correlate with increasing CAG repeat length, with HD manifesting in patients carrying 40 or more CAG repeats.
HD is the most common polyQ repeat disease, with a prevalence of at least 1 in 10.
The patient group for IBS is very heterogeneous and characterized by abdominal pain, discomfort, and abnormal bowel habits.
The pathophysiology of IBS is unknown, and the heterogeneous patient material suggests multiple explanations for symptom development.
Patient groups for IBS are currently subdivided into IBS with diarrhea (IBS-D), IBS with constipation (IBS-C), or IBS with mixed bowel habits (IBS-M).
No single unifying cause for IBS has been reported, but several factors have been associated with its disease etiology, including genetics.

Unlike the less aggressive davfs of the lateral and cavernous sinuses, which drain into venous sinuses, tentorial davfs drain into pial veins.

Middle ear cholesteatoma is characterized by keratinocytic hyperproliferation, bony destruction, and granulation tissue due to chronic inflammation.
There are four basic theories of the pathogenesis of middle ear cholesteatoma: invagination, basal cell hyperplasia, epithelial ingrowth, and squamous metaplasia.
The pathogenesis of middle ear cholesteatoma has been debated for a century, and a unanimous concept does not exist.
From a histological perspective, the interaction between cellular components is essential for the major histopathological features of cholesteatoma, including hyperproliferation and bone destruction.
In 1964, the American anatomist Gray referred to middle ear cholesteatoma as 'skin in' the middle ear.

Permanent postoperative hypoparathyroidism results from the unintentional removal or injury of parathyroid glands during thyroid and parathyroid surgery.
Permanent hypoparathyroidism is defined as persistent hypocalcemia requiring calcium and vitamin D supplementation 6 months after surgery.

The risk of hypoparathyroidism is nominal during a minimally invasive parathyroidectomy for a single adenoma but is greatest after a subtotal or total parathyroidectomy, thyroid resection and nodal dissection for large and extensive thyroid cancers, and reoperative neck operations.

Even though the risk of transient hypocalcemia can be high during an extensive neck dissection, the permanent hypoparathyroidism rate is typically around 1% in the hands of experienced endocrine surgeons at high-volume centers.

Fatigue is the most frequent symptom in multiple sclerosis (MS).
The multiple sclerosis council defines MS-related fatigue as a subjective lack of physical and/or mental energy that interferes with usual and desired activities.

The structure consists of a pair of cylindrically shaped centrioles surrounded by fibrous pericentriolar material.
Before or during DNA replication in S phase, the centrioles split, and each cylinder serves as a template for the assembly of a new daughter centriole.
Before mitosis, when cells contain two pairs of centrioles, each pair serves as a nucleation center for microtubules of the spindle apparatus.
Defects in centrosome assembly or in centrosome separation can result in defective nucleation of spindle microtubules and in several cases, in the formation of monopolar spindles and mitotic arrest.
Several years ago, evidence was published that defective centrosome assembly can prevent cells from entering S phase.
In particular, removal of the centrosome by microsurgery can prevent cells from entering S phase.
